rules.title: Partizip I (Present Participle)
rules.description: Formed by adding '-d' to the infinitive. Used as an adjective or adverb.
examples: das spielende Kind (the playing child)
die laufende Frau (the running woman)
ein wachsender Baum (a growing tree)
rules.notes: When used as an adjective, it takes regular adjective endings.

rules.title: Extended Adjective Constructions
rules.description: Complex adjectival phrases that come before the noun, common in formal German.
examples: die im letzten Jahr veröffentlichte Studie (the study published last year)
der gestern angefangene Bericht (the report started yesterday)
das von vielen Experten empfohlene Buch (the book recommended by many experts)
rules.notes: These constructions can be replaced with relative clauses in spoken German.

rules.title: Nominalization
rules.description: Converting verbs and adjectives into nouns, a common feature in formal German.
examples: laufen → das Laufen (to run → running)
schön → die Schönheit (beautiful → beauty)
freundlich → die Freundlichkeit (friendly → friendliness)
rules.notes: Nominalized verbs are always neuter. Adjectives use suffixes like -heit, -keit, -ung.

rules.title: Future Perfect (Futur II)
rules.description: Describes an action that will be completed by a certain time in the future.
examples: Ich werde das Buch gelesen haben. (I will have read the book.)
Sie wird angekommen sein. (She will have arrived.)
Bis morgen werden wir fertig sein. (By tomorrow we will be finished.)
rules.notes: Formed with werden + past participle + haben/sein.

rules.title: Partizip II (Past Participle) as Adjective
rules.description: Past participles can function as adjectives with appropriate endings.
examples: das gekochte Ei (the boiled egg)
die gelesenen Bücher (the read books)
ein geöffnetes Fenster (an opened window)
der reparierte Wagen (the repaired car)
rules.notes: Shows a completed action. Takes regular adjective endings based on case, gender, and number.

rules.title: Passive Voice with Modal Verbs
rules.description: Combining passive constructions with modal verbs to express necessity, possibility, etc.
examples: Das Auto muss repariert werden. (The car must be repaired.)
Der Brief kann heute geschickt werden. (The letter can be sent today.)
Die Aufgabe soll bis morgen erledigt werden. (The task should be completed by tomorrow.)
Das Problem konnte gelöst werden. (The problem could be solved.)
rules.notes: Structure: modal verb + past participle + werden. In perfect tense: modal + participle + worden + sein.

rules.title: Konjunktiv II for Wishes and Regrets
rules.description: Expressing wishes, dreams, and regrets using Konjunktiv II.
examples: Wenn ich doch reich wäre! (If only I were rich!)
Hätte ich das nur gewusst! (If only I had known that!)
Wäre ich doch zu Hause geblieben! (If only I had stayed home!)
Ich wünschte, ich könnte fliegen. (I wish I could fly.)
rules.notes: Often uses 'wenn...doch' or 'nur' for emphasis. Past wishes use hätte/wäre + past participle.

rules.title: Alternatives to Passive Voice
rules.description: Using 'man', 'sich lassen', or other constructions instead of passive.
examples: Man spricht hier Deutsch. (German is spoken here.)
Das lässt sich leicht erklären. (That can be easily explained.)
Das Buch ist leicht zu lesen. (The book is easy to read.)
Der Text ist schwer zu verstehen. (The text is difficult to understand.)
rules.notes: 'Man' is common in speech, 'sich lassen' implies possibility, 'zu + infinitive' shows feasibility.

rules.title: Word Formation with Prefixes
rules.description: Using prefixes to change or intensify the meaning of verbs and adjectives.
examples: ver-: kaufen → verkaufen (to sell), stehen → verstehen (to understand)
be-: kommen → bekommen (to receive), suchen → besuchen (to visit)
ent-: decken → entdecken (to discover), wickeln → entwickeln (to develop)
un-: möglich → unmöglich (impossible), glücklich → unglücklich (unhappy)
rules.notes: Inseparable prefixes (be-, emp-, ent-, er-, ge-, miss-, ver-, zer-) have no 'ge-' in past participle.

rules.title: Word Formation with Suffixes
rules.description: Using suffixes to create nouns from verbs and adjectives.
examples: -ung: bedeuten → die Bedeutung (meaning), wohnen → die Wohnung (apartment)
-heit/-keit: krank → die Krankheit (illness), möglich → die Möglichkeit (possibility)
-er: lehren → der Lehrer (teacher), arbeiten → der Arbeiter (worker)
-schaft: freund → die Freundschaft (friendship), wissen → die Wissenschaft (science)
rules.notes: These suffixes determine the gender: -ung, -heit, -keit, -schaft are feminine; -er is masculine.

rules.title: Expressing Purpose (um...zu, damit)
rules.description: Using 'um...zu' or 'damit' to express the purpose or goal of an action.
examples: Ich lerne Deutsch, um in Deutschland zu arbeiten. (I'm learning German in order to work in Germany.)
Sie geht früh ins Bett, um morgen fit zu sein. (She goes to bed early to be fit tomorrow.)
Ich rufe dich an, damit du Bescheid weißt. (I'm calling you so that you know.)
Er spricht langsam, damit alle ihn verstehen. (He speaks slowly so that everyone understands him.)
rules.notes: Use 'um...zu' when subjects are the same. Use 'damit' when subjects differ.

rules.title: Relative Pronouns in All Cases
rules.description: Using relative pronouns in nominative, accusative, dative, and genitive cases.
examples: Nominative: Der Mann, der dort steht... (The man who stands there...)
Accusative: Das Buch, das ich lese... (The book that I'm reading...)
Dative: Die Frau, der ich helfe... (The woman whom I help...)
Genitive: Der Mann, dessen Auto rot ist... (The man whose car is red...)
rules.notes: Relative pronouns match the gender/number of the antecedent but take the case from their role in the relative clause.

rules.title: Conjunctional Adverbs
rules.description: Adverbs that connect sentences logically: deshalb, trotzdem, außerdem, etc.
examples: Es regnet. Deshalb bleibe ich zu Hause. (It's raining. Therefore I'm staying home.)
Er ist müde. Trotzdem arbeitet er weiter. (He's tired. Nevertheless he continues working.)
Sie lernt Deutsch. Außerdem lernt sie Spanisch. (She's learning German. Additionally she's learning Spanish.)
Das Wetter ist schlecht. Dennoch gehen wir spazieren. (The weather is bad. Nevertheless we're going for a walk.)
rules.notes: These cause verb-second word order. The adverb occupies position 1, verb in position 2.

rules.title: Verbal Nouns in Context
rules.description: Using nominalized infinitives in various grammatical contexts.
examples: Das Rauchen ist hier verboten. (Smoking is forbidden here.)
Beim Lesen schlafe ich oft ein. (I often fall asleep while reading.)
Zum Kochen brauche ich Zeit. (I need time for cooking.)
Vor dem Essen waschen wir uns die Hände. (Before eating we wash our hands.)
rules.notes: Always neuter (das). Can be used with prepositions: beim, zum, vor dem, nach dem.

rules.title: Advanced Negation Strategies
rules.description: Various ways to negate beyond basic 'nicht' and 'kein'.
examples: weder...noch: Ich habe weder Zeit noch Geld. (I have neither time nor money.)
keineswegs: Das ist keineswegs einfach. (That is by no means simple.)
kaum: Ich habe kaum geschlafen. (I barely slept.)
niemals: Das werde ich niemals tun. (I will never do that.)
rules.notes: These provide nuanced ways to express different types and degrees of negation.

rules.title: Fixed Expressions with 'es'
rules.description: Common idiomatic expressions and constructions using 'es'.
examples: Es geht mir gut. (I'm doing well.)
Es tut mir leid. (I'm sorry.)
Es kommt darauf an. (It depends.)
Es gibt... (There is/are...)
Es handelt sich um... (It concerns/is about...)
Es fällt mir schwer/leicht. (It's difficult/easy for me.)
rules.notes: These are fixed expressions where 'es' cannot be replaced or omitted.

rules.title: Attributive Genitive
rules.description: Using genitive to show possession and relationships, common in formal writing.
examples: die Erfindung des Computers (the invention of the computer)
die Entwicklung der Technologie (the development of technology)
das Ende des Krieges (the end of the war)
die Hauptstadt Deutschlands (the capital of Germany)
rules.notes: In speech, often replaced by 'von + dative'. Genitive is preferred in formal/written German.

rules.title: Tense in Reported Speech
rules.description: Maintaining or shifting tenses when reporting what someone said.
examples: Direct: 'Ich bin müde.' → Indirect: Er sagte, er sei müde. (He said he was tired.)
Direct: 'Ich habe gegessen.' → Indirect: Sie sagte, sie habe gegessen. (She said she had eaten.)
Direct: 'Ich werde kommen.' → Indirect: Er sagte, er werde kommen. (He said he would come.)
rules.notes: Uses Konjunktiv I in formal contexts. Tense relationship is maintained from original statement.

rules.title: Concessive Clauses (obwohl, trotzdem)
rules.description: Expressing contrast or unexpected outcomes.
examples: Obwohl es regnet, gehe ich spazieren. (Although it's raining, I'm going for a walk.)
Trotz des Regens gehe ich spazieren. (Despite the rain, I'm going for a walk.)
Es regnet. Trotzdem gehe ich spazieren. (It's raining. Nevertheless I'm going for a walk.)
So müde ich auch bin, ich muss arbeiten. (However tired I am, I must work.)
rules.notes: 'Obwohl' is a subordinating conjunction (verb to end), 'trotzdem' is an adverb (verb second).

rules.title: Emphatic Structures
rules.description: Using various structures to emphasize particular elements.
examples: Das war es, was ich sagen wollte. (That was what I wanted to say.)
Er ist es, der mir geholfen hat. (He is the one who helped me.)
Gerade deshalb mache ich das. (That's exactly why I'm doing this.)
Ausgerechnet heute muss es regnen! (Of all days, it has to rain today!)
rules.notes: Various particles and constructions can add emphasis: gerade, ausgerechnet, eben, doch.
